Class OddEven

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Selection
mz.Bubble
mz.OddEven
All Implemented Interfaces:
SelectionInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortFind<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroOddEven
public class OddEven extends Bubble
The Odd-even (Brick) Sort algorithm is a variation of the Bubble Sort algorithm that is specifically designed to sort arrays in parallel. It works by comparing and swapping adjacent elements in pairs repeatedly until the array is sorted.
Since:
1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • OddEven

      public OddEven()
      Odd-even (Brick) Sort:
      The Odd-even Sort algorithm is a variation of the Bubble Sort algorithm that is specifically designed to sort arrays in parallel. It works by comparing and swapping adjacent elements in pairs repeatedly until the array is sorted.

      Example:
      1. Start with an unsorted array of elements.
      2. Repeat the following steps until the array is sorted:
        • Compare and swap adjacent elements in pairs, starting from the first and second elements.
        • Compare and swap adjacent elements in pairs, starting from the second and third elements.
        • Continue alternating between odd and even adjacent element comparisons and swaps until the last pair of elements.
      3. After each iteration, the largest element in the unsorted portion of the array will move to its correct position at the end.
      4. Repeat the above steps until the entire array is sorted.
      Note:
      The odd-even sort algorithm works well for parallel computing because the comparisons and swaps can be performed independently on different pairs of elements. However, it is not as efficient as some other sorting algorithms, and it has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2), where n is the number of elements to be sorted.

      Transposition sort is a stable sorting algorithm. This means that it maintains the relative order of elements with equal values during the sorting process. If two elements have the same value, the algorithm will not swap them unless their relative order is disturbed by other adjacent elements.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Average Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Auxiliary Space: O(1)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQOddEven
      • IntroOddEven

    • oddEvenInc

      protected void oddEvenInc(Comparable[] array)
      oddEvenInc that takes an array of Comparable objects as a parameter. The method aims to sort the array in an incremental order using the odd-even sort algorithm.
      • The method begins by initializing a boolean variable named isSorted to false. This variable will serve as a flag to indicate whether the array is sorted or not.
      • There is a while loop that continues until isSorted is true. Within the loop, the value of isSorted is set to true to assume that the array is already sorted.
      • The indexedElementInc method is then called twice within the loop.
        • The first call passes the array, index 1, and the length of the array as parameters.
        • The second call passes the array, index 0, and the length of the array as parameters.
      • The purpose of these calls is to check if the indexed elements of the array are sorted in incremental order. The indexedElementInc method, returns true if the elements at the specified indices do not require any swaps to achieve incremental order, and false otherwise.
      • If any of the indexedElementInc calls return false, it means that at least one swap was performed to achieve the desired order. In such cases, the isSorted variable is set to false, indicating that the array is not completely sorted.
      • The while loop continues until both indexedElementInc calls return true, indicating that the entire array is sorted in incremental order.
      oddEvenInc method repeatedly calls the indexedElementInc method on alternating indices to sort the array using the odd-even sort algorithm until the entire array is sorted in incremental order.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • indexedElementInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • oddEvenDec

      protected void oddEvenDec(Comparable[] array)
      oddEvenDec that takes an array of Comparable objects as a parameter. The method aims to sort the array in a decremental order using the odd-even sort algorithm.
      • The method begins by initializing a boolean variable named isSorted to false. This variable will serve as a flag to indicate whether the array is sorted or not.
      • There is a while loop that continues until isSorted is true. Within the loop, the value of isSorted is set to true to assume that the array is already sorted.
      • The indexedElementDec method is then called twice within the loop.
        • The first call passes the array, index 1, and the length of the array as parameters.
        • The second call passes the array, index 0, and the length of the array as parameters.
      • The purpose of these calls is to check if the indexed elements of the array are sorted in decremental order. The indexedElementDec method, returns true if the elements at the specified indices do not require any swaps to achieve decremental order, and false otherwise.
      • If any of the indexedElementDec calls return false, it means that at least one swap was performed to achieve the desired order. In such cases, the isSorted variable is set to false, indicating that the array is not completely sorted.
      • The while loop continues until both indexedElementDec calls return true, indicating that the entire array is sorted in decremental order.
      oddEvenInc method repeatedly calls the indexedElementDec method on alternating indices to sort the array using the odd-even sort algorithm until the entire array is sorted in decremental order.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • indexedElementDec(Comparable[], int, int)

    • oddEvenInc

      protected void oddEvenInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      oddEvenInc that takes an array of Comparable objects, an integer left, and an integer right. The method aims to sort the array in an incremental order using the odd-even sort algorithm.
      • The method starts by initializing a boolean variable named isSorted to false, indicating that the array range is initially unsorted.
      • there is a while loop that continues until isSorted is true. Within the loop, the value of isSorted is set to true to assume that the array range is already sorted.
      • The indexedElementInc method is called twice within the loop.
        • The first call passes the array, (left + 1), and right as parameters.
        • The second call passes the array, left, and right as parameters.
      • The purpose of these calls is to check if the indexed elements of the array range are sorted in incremental order. The indexedElementInc method, as previously discussed, returns true if the elements at the specified indices within the range do not require any swaps to achieve incremental order, and false otherwise.
      • If any of the indexedElementInc calls return false, indicating that at least one swap was performed within the range, the isSorted variable is set to false, indicating that the array range is not completely sorted.
      • The while loop continues until both indexedElementInc calls return true, indicating that the specified array range is sorted in incremental order.
      oddEvenInc method sorts a specific range of the array using the odd-even sort algorithm by repeatedly calling the indexedElementInc method on alternating indices within the range until the range is completely sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - specific range of the array.
      right - specific range of the array.
      See Also:
      • indexedElementInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • oddEvenDec

      protected void oddEvenDec(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      oddEvenDec that takes an array of Comparable objects, an integer left, and an integer right. The method aims to sort the array in a decremental order using the odd-even sort algorithm.
      • The method starts by initializing a boolean variable named isSorted to false, indicating that the array range is initially unsorted.
      • there is a while loop that continues until isSorted is true. Within the loop, the value of isSorted is set to true to assume that the array range is already sorted.
      • The indexedElementDec method is called twice within the loop.
        • The first call passes the array, (left + 1), and right as parameters.
        • The second call passes the array, left, and right as parameters.
      • The purpose of these calls is to check if the indexed elements of the array range are sorted in decremental order. The indexedElementDec method, as previously discussed, returns true if the elements at the specified indices within the range do not require any swaps to achieve decremental order, and false otherwise.
      • If any of the indexedElementDec calls return false, indicating that at least one swap was performed within the range, the isSorted variable is set to false, indicating that the array range is not completely sorted.
      • The while loop continues until both indexedElementDec calls return true, indicating that the specified array range is sorted in decremental order.
      oddEvenDec method sorts a specific range of the array using the odd-even sort algorithm by repeatedly calling the indexedElementDec method on alternating indices within the range until the range is completely sorted.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - specific range of the array.
      right - specific range of the array.
      See Also:
      • indexedElementDec(Comparable[], int, int)

    • indexedElementInc

      protected boolean indexedElementInc(Comparable[] array, int j, int n)
      indexedElementInc that takes an array of Comparable objects, an integer j, and an integer n as parameters. The method iterates through the array elements starting from index j and incrementing the index by 2 in each iteration until reaching (n - 2).
      • Within the for loop, the method calls another method named isSwapInc and passes the array, the current index i, and the value 1 as parameters.
      • If the isSwapInc method returns true, indicating that swapping the elements would result in an incremental order, the element variable is set to false, indicating that there was at least one swap required to achieve the desired order.
      indexedElementInc the method returns the value of the element variable, which would be true if no swaps were needed or false if at least one swap occurred.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      j - the array elements starting from index.
      n - the array elements ending from index.
      Returns:
      true if there was no exchange.
      false if there was at least 1 exchange.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.isSwapInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • indexedElementDec

      protected boolean indexedElementDec(Comparable[] array, int j, int n)
      indexedElementDec that takes an array of Comparable objects, an integer j, and an integer n as parameters. The method iterates through the array elements starting from index j and incrementing the index by 2 in each iteration until reaching (n - 2).
      • Within the for loop, the method calls another method named isSwapDec and passes the array, the current index i, and the value 1 as parameters.
      • If the isSwapDec method returns true, indicating that swapping the elements would result in and decremental order, the element variable is set to false, indicating that there was at least one swap required to achieve the desired order.
      indexedElementDec the method returns the value of the element variable, which would be true if no swaps were needed or false if at least one swap occurred.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      j - the array elements starting from index.
      n - the array elements ending from index.
      Returns:

      false if there was at least 1 exchange.
